A year ago the secret thing befell That lays me in my grave.... No name, device, Atonement, faith can help a man to die: Upon myself alone I lean, my deeds, My thoughts, that which I know and am: Mistake me not; I go despairing down To dust and deep oblivion.... Once, indeed, It seemed to me no stronger brain than mine Repelled the problems of the Universe, That none so proud against obsession bade Belief produce its passport, none despised Opinion so profoundly, served and groomed A nature so anointed to shake off The venom of remorse; yet here I lie A broken man, who stood a year ago The foremost of his time, the heart and brain Of Britain and her Empire; unassailed By calumny, by every faction mourned, Last victim of the old conspiracy, The plot eternal none unravels, pierced By nameless foes, impalpable, unseen, Yet omnipresent, yet omnipotent; Undone by mystery, smitten by a thought, A poisoned arrow from the infinite. Or is it that my spirit slays itself? A doubter always, I; and doubt is deathâ Therefore to be desired, since all things end? Death is desirable, but not by doubt: The doom of doubt is to be pressed to death By awful certainty as now I lie, Spectator, sufferer, auditor of pangs Unbearable, stretched out in deepest Hell Under the overpowering Universe. When I became the master of the world It seemed indeed an admirable ruseâ For all was ruse and compromise I thoughtâ Whereby the State, in magic leading-strings Of dialectic, moped and roamed about Its labyrinthine businesses, or hung Unheeding on the brink of anarchy. Miraculous too, it was, to hear men lie Against each other as the only means And menstruum of truth; to watch debate Lixiviate matters till the recrement Appeared, the perfect, smooth, exhausted sludge That blinds the electorate and chokes it off. This was the legacy of patriotism! And still I deemed it the adjusted helm Of government, forgettingâfolk forget!â That greatness but a moment dominates The wayward chance of systems as of men. Inevitable decadence of powers Political, in English battlefields Established, fostered oft with native blood, Matured in Parliaments, and dying now, Debased survivals starved amid the rank Usurping thicket of the Fourth Estate, Publicity that overthrows cabal, Affords opinions, nostrums, men and things Of every standing opportunity, And is the only true tyrannicide: This decadence of Parliament I thought An aftermath, a precious verdigris, A genial mellowing in the weathered bronze Of our palladium; for the sorcery That charms the soul of England, party-led, Enchanted me and held in every sphere My spirit spellbound. Pratice and belief? Antipodes: the one in power and place; The other to oppose, condemn, destroy: The Governmentâthe sinner and the sin; The Oppositionâthe evangelist To break its pride, to chasten, scourge and turn The pageant of its power, a draggled show, Into the narrow way. âThe Universeâ âThis specious Universe,â I thought, âthat hangs âSo balanced, so complete, remains within âUntuned, corrupt, a hidden chaos masked âWith mere cosmetic; wisest thought and best, âHeroic deed, most beautiful device, âConsummate law and polity of man âSeem so to him, but are inane and void; âFor out of chaos only chaos comes. âThe green and sapphire earth embossed with studs âOf crystal snow at either lonely pole; âWith orient dawn, with sunset in the west, âThe sumptuous rubies of its girdle clasped; âAnd wearing gallantly, day in day out, âIts azure mantle of ethereal dust, âThat turns at night a sable domino âWith stars embroidered....â Beauty, tenderness, The love, the passion, the humanity, The soul of man has wasted on the world! A year ago, I say, this thing befell That lays me in my grave. I rose in wrath Against the fools and rabble of the House That picked at him, the keystone of our bridge, The linch-pin of the wheel of government, The genius of the State: âThe very soulââ I had your new philosopheme in mind, Defending him, my friend, his power and planâ âThe very soul of culture now is trade. âThink you I love it, I, conservative, âAfraid of novelty, a child among âThe doctrinaires, a stranger in the House âThough foremost there; only at home in thought? âI love it not; but how should that concern âThe automatic forces of the world! âThe Golden Age returns, or rather say, âThat dream fulfils itself; for waking dreams âAre tokens of our Fate the debtor Time âDischarges duly in the current coin. âYou had your Age of Stone, your Age of Bronze, âWhen baffled wonder, ignorance, terror, awe âTogether knit, made up a soul in man âThat fenced itself about with arts and rites, âOr found escape and refuge, hope and joy âIn fearless fancy and heroic love. âThen came the Iron Age, impassioned, brief, âA centuryâno more: it ends with us. âThis was the Age the Revolution tore âInhuman from the labouring womb of Time â(Inhuman or over-human; nothing at all âIs more inherent in humanity âThan inhumanity). This was the Age, âThat showed once more how one man's might may knead âThe world like dough and bake it in a cakeâ âAnd how the wise man like the fool essays âTo eat his cake and have it. Iron age âSpecific, unmistakable, of guns, âOf armour-plate, of engines, wheels, machines; âOf iron knowledge, iron thought: the Age âWherein at last the Iron Book of Fate âLay open to the world. This Iron Age âWas Doomsday like a robber in the night âRifling the sanctuary; Doomsday and a new âAuthentic Dispensation. First came Law; âThereafter, Love; and now Intelligence, âFor now at last we know, and all is now âPermitted. Not an accident, nor made âBy any power demonic or divine, âBut Matter, Substance, Universe become âSelf-consciousâby its own innate desire âInvincibly impelled through trials, tests âOf instinct and brutalityâMan crowns âThe adventurous effort: Matter knows itself; âAnd Man, the organ of its knowledge, bound âFor ever on this torture-wheel the earth, âIn agony confesses what he isâ âNot God, nor Devil, but Material stuff âThat knows and thinks, imagines and despairs, âEndures and wills. After the Iron Age âWe reach the Age of Goldâthe dream come true âOf Pagan and of Christian. Soberly âI say, this twentieth century begins âNo other Age than the Millennium. âIn every time and clime the cry has been ââEscape! escape!â The future beckoned still âReplete with immaterial happiness, âAnd stubborn man imagined things diverse âFrom those that have been, and will always be, âAnd never can be other than they are. âBut now we know escape impossible; âAnd on the tolling of that knowledge comes âThe Golden Age, Millennium, Heaven-and-Hellâ âThat have been always though men knew it not; âFor knowledge to the subject of it makes âThe character of things. Oh, Matter means âThat Man shall not escape! A way there isâ âBy death; and every leaf resolves again âTo inorganic dust and fumes unseen; âBut the tree dies not; and the sighing woods âAre powerless not to thrive. I stood one day âAnd watched a grove of beeches: fluted stems, âWith knots and bosses where the boiling sap âHad burst the rind; with intertwining boughs, âAs if they stood impatient for the dance âAnd waiting on the word to break the spell âThat held them root-bound. For the younger ones, âThe slender saplings, with their branches draped âSo gracefully about themâsure, the spell âHad been dissolved already; but they, too, âWere waiting, haply for the older trees âTo lead the way, or for some idle whim. âAnd as I watched I thought: The charm will soon âBe wrought again before these wanton plants âMake up their minds to trip it down the hill, âForsake their native grove and see the world; âAnd the sharpset, remorseless axe may be âTheir only disenchanter, at a time âWhen to be conscious of the rising sap âWould please them well enough, to be assured âOnly of this that they are not yet dead. âSo is it with the nations and the tribes, âThe classes, masses, peoples of the earth: âThe leaves, the men and women, die and rot; âBut the trees stand, Goth, Scythian, Mongol, Jew, âFoolish and wise, the strong men and the weak, âThe sighing woods, the world-wide wilderness: âThe fixed idea, Humankind, remains âUntil the earth becomes an icicle, âOr falls into the bosom of the sun. âWatching the world as once I watched the trees, âI think how much more happy, more renowned, âThe destiny of those whose long decay âDistresses tender hearts, if tribes and clans, âMan, woman, child, in splendid unison âThey had themselves before their spirit broke âDestroyed the spell of life that held them fast: âThe Red Men of the west, the strength austere, âThe adamantine nerve that worshipped pain; âInvented cruelties and took delight âTo witness and to die in agony, âSo various, so protracted, so intense âThat to the tortured Indian at the stakeâ âA thing of use-and-wont, a festivalâ âThe Crucifixion seemed a pleasant dream; âOr that offscouring of the Eastern world, âThe melancholy Celt, whom Latin, Greek âAnd Teuton drove through Europe to the rocks, âThe utmost isles and precincts of the sea, âWho fight for fighting's sake and understand âNo meaning in defeat, having no cause âAt heart, no depth of purpose, no profound âDesire, no inspiration, no belief, âA twilight people living in a dream, âA withered dream they never had themselves, âA faded heirloom that their fathers dreamt: âHow much more happy these had they destroyed âThe spell of life at once, and so escaped âAn unregarded martyrdom, the consciousness âOf inefficience and the world's contempt! âBut Matter, firm that Man shall not escape âWhile earth remains inhabitable, knits âHis vehement spirit of Material stuff, âOf longing infinite that will exist. âTherefore it is that with the starless time âOf actual knowledge and intelligence âThe Golden Age appearsâthis darksome dawn âOf ours, a day-in-night, a night-in-day: âFor whether earth already to its doom âReels orbit-slipped, or whether decades hence, âOr next year, or to-morrow, or to-day âThe weight of ice amassed at either pole âShall change our axis till a deluge wipe âThe citied world away, and glacial drift âPlough up the earth and harrow it again; âOr whether flame consume us comet-struck; âOr the earth's crust fall in; or to the sun âReturning whence it sprang, our orb effete, âEnwombed in pristine fire once more, become âThe brilliant seed of stars to be, we know âThat men shall cease: their speech, their deeds, their arts, âThe wonder of their being, passion, love, âAmbition, charity, transcendent thought âShall leave no memory, token, sign, or sigh âIn any speck of dust, or nook of space; âWe know that here and now is Heaven-and-Hell; âThis is the Promised Land, the Golden Age, âThis, the Millennium, and the Aftertime, âThe fixed, eternal moment, sounding on. âSo for our purpose let the passing mood âSuffice: we enter now the Golden Age, âAn early dream of Matter's. Nether-formed âIn molten rocks antique, and woven athwart âMethodic minerals by the wandering veins âThat traverse ordered masses, Gold implied âA Golden Age; and when its hour awoke âIn consciousness by simple means of truth âPerceived at last, the metal once again âIn ancient Ophir shone and newer lands, âPredestined to be ours, enriched the world âWith rivers, harvests, spathes and pits of gold. âGet Gold, get Gold; and be the Golden Age! âSo signals Matter from the ends of the earth âWhere'er her chosen people pitch their tents. âReligion, chivalry, crusade, romance, âOr war for war's own sake, or art for art, âFreedom for Man, and Justice for the World âAre not; or are contained in thisâGet Gold! âOne nation must be richer than the rest: âLet it be ours! it must, it will be ours âIf we continue Matter's best belov'd.â. . . Right there it was my wondering heart o'erthrew My argument, and flooded all my thought, An inundation of humanity That drowned Material truth. The soldier, starved, Corrupted, tortured into cowardice! (All men are brave by nature, and in health, Well-fed and at their ease, as men should be, Would scorn to do another's bidding.) Souls In factories shred! Unwilling sex profaned! (All women are by nature chaste as fire: How otherwise could chastity be thought!) Soft bosoms strewn with ashes; tender hearts, Dried, tanned and stretched from belted wheel to wheel; And all the noisomeness that's daily cleansed In women's tears! The horror of the world Wherein its wealth and power are rooted fastâ Blossom and savoury fruit, carnation-hued And teeming with delight for every sense, Out of the offal and the excrement Distilled, the essence of humanity Expressed from putrid masses of mankind: This surged upon me, sobbing wave on wave That throttled speech: I stammered to a close, Then left the House. Borne on this tide I went By the uncouth embankment where the Thames In surface eddies coiling and uncoiled, Entangled by a myriad, myriad keels, Propellers, paddles, turbines, dredgers, oars, A ravelled skein, a dismal flood winds down Its greasy channel: past St. Paul's that looms Above the thunder of the multitude, Shouldering the skies; along tumultuous streets Of warehouse, factory, bank, by dock and wharf, Until I reached a loathsome region, foul, Malodorous, dark; in every separate pore Of noxious atmosphere a separate stench. Among the barges, plots of pasturage Like old unhealed abrasions opened up With sheep like maggots starving in the mud. The reaches of the tributary Lea, Enamelled filthily in many huesâ Purple and faded crimson, pallid gold And swarthy soot in wrinkled creasesâgleamed With dusky iridescence, and bewitched My wounded fancy like a hellish charm. Ashamed I tracked the hideous watercourse And lit upon a swamp, a festering swamp, An ugly gusset of unholy slime Where stunted hemlock fought with tufts of sedge. It lay a little lower than the Lea, And took a ropy overflow that slunk Beneath a ruined bridge: tall chimney-stalks On one side belching smoke; the river bank Upon another; on the third, relays Of jangling trains: a piece of mother earth, Most woebegone, most horrible, for years Imprisoned, sick with filth and fetid air, Irrecognizable. Upon the bridge Some human lumber loafed, a dozen men Incompetent or drunken; all unfit For everything except survival. One, An old man, toothless, tremulous, unclean, His face and temples crumpled out of shape By seventy years' essay to thrust and fix His angularity in useful rounds Of business, eagerly harangued the group: âConceive it, grasp it, hoard it in your minds, âA new possession that illumines all: âSelf-consciousness is Matter's seamy side; âMan is the seamy side of the Universe: âHere for a while the Universe disports âItself, a motley clown, wearing its coat âOf many colours inside out: the truth, âNearer than any saying ever came âBefore, in that fantastic image hides.â âYes,â cried another, drunk, irrelevant, Ragged, consumptive, horrible: âMy tears âThat scald my sunken cheeks, salter than brine âWith long retention:âwhy I weep at last, âWhy here, I cannot tell:âthis sweated blood âThat brands like vitriol; sobs that shake the world; âThis outcry that might rend the veil, and ring âThrough space to startle slumberous overtones âUnheard among the silent sinful spheres âExcept when woe awakes them: these avouch âA Christian and the winepress of his creed. âI, last of all the Christians, trembling yet, âUpon the verge and crumbling brink of Hell, âAssaulted momently by doubts and fears âDespite the proven panoply of faith, âAnd tortured out of all similitude âTo humankind, can pray this meagre prayerâ ââLord I believe; help Thou, mine unbelief!ââ He knelt unnoticed by the rest, for these Were heedless of each other, stripped and flayed Of all save personality. âFor me,â Another cried: âI'm atheist, stark: a God âWould long ago have killed me, I being I, âA mystery of iniquity.â âAnd I,â Said one, snuffling with half a palate, lips Of shapeless sponge and rotting nose, âI say âThere is a God: I know His handiwork; âI bear His marks about me: not a God âThat shifts and doubles with the moods of men; âBut He that Is, the old remorseless Jew âWho took his pound of flesh on Calvary: âHim I believe in.â âWell,â another cried, Asquint at me: âwhat do you think of us? âGreat men, I wager, mate?â âStrange men, at least. âHow were you sifted out and cast away?â âBy being gratefulââthus the eager wretch Who thought Humanity the seamy side Of Matter: âgratitude, sheer gratitude âDestroys the courage, eats the soul out, stuffs âThe pockets of the wise who feel it not. âBe grateful if you must, but never tell; âOr else the world will use your gratitude âTo starve you out; and slave or mendicant âWill be your doom.â âAstonishing,â I said, âTo find a humorist here.â âA humorist? Hell!â Snorted the monster that believed in God. âNo humorists here: we are the men who know. âYour belletristic prattle! What a lie âThat humour is the salt of literature, âThe truest truth of life! The Book of books? âCome; what's the humour there? What's Dante's? Grim? âThe humour of the Crucifixion? True; âThe brilliant humour of the fire of Hell, âAnd, as you said, the humorousness of us.â âHow can you live?â I cried. âHow dare to live?â âWe are the only folk who are alive,â Their eldest spokesman said. âThe seamy side? âThe naked nerves of Matter! Matter loves âIts aches and pains: it knows itself thereby. âWe hate to labour; love to brood and dream. âWork cures or kills us; but we won't be cured. âMatter has need of drunken idlers, fit âTo loaf and think, to understand the world, âAnd be its fiercest pangs of consciousness.â âLet all men,â said the Atheist, âclass or mass, âTread on the mouths of cowards; scorn success; âReject imaginative solace, dreams, âDelusions of desire; abandon hope; âAnd sick or sound, in prison or exempt, âOr chained or tortured daily, mock the doom âOf humankind, and with a lewd grimace âDeride the covert nakedness of Fateâ âSo thinly clad, so foolish, so ashamed.â My soul grew pallid; but I spoke: âOh fools, âUnhallowed outcasts, spirits petrified âIn evil, human lumber, self-removed, âSelf-damned, do something were it but to fight âAmong yourselves and find out which is first. âForget that men like you afflict the world: âThink of the great onesââ Such a husky noise Broke out about me, spluttering like a vat O'ercloyed with heat that boils its surfeit off Bestirred upon a sudden! âGreat ones? Hell! âWe are the great ones, we.âââAbove, beneath, âAbout me, or within, nothing is great: âI only, I am great: greater than thought. âSpirit and flesh, my casual qualities: âBut I, the individual, I am more âThan soul and body: insubmissive me.ââ âThe Ego? Ha, the Ego! Who shall name, âWho say it, who define!âââWhy, every man âIs every instant instantly himself, âExactly what he is; no more, no less.ââ âI am the only individual, I: âThe Truth itself is nothing: to believe âThe highest Truth would be to abdicate âThe individual: all things disappear âBefore the sovereign Me.â From out those cries Of personality upon the rack A mellow voice, a voice sustained, arose With one who stood a head above the rest, Upstarting from a silent session, he, Alone of those who hung about the bridge In tune with Fate and master of the mood. âI knew the greatest man that ever lived,â He said, and all gave place, nodding their heads In quick approval as at something found By happy chance when diligence had failed. âI knew the greatest man that ever lived. âFirst, let me ask you, have you felt at all âThe torment of the mind when life depends âOn pleasing othersâraiment, food, abode âExtorted by the labour of the hands âFrom grudging capital, or won by toil âOf fettered brains, abuse of gift, or waste âOf patience in some idle service, theft âDirect, deceit, or mendicancy? No? âHow can I make you truly apprehend âThe eating cancer in the soul of man âDependent for a livelihood? On sin âThe sumptuous worships, empires, orders, arts âAre 'stablished, nourished, drunken, wanton, madâ âThe inevitable, never-pardoned sin âOf procreants who fill the earth with souls âThat must be slaves: it is the only sinâ âTo thrust a human being on the world: âI say it simply. Inconceivable âThis agony of indigence! No tongue, âNo sound can utter it: absorbent pain âThat from the blood the iron colour draws, âPrecludes the rich distillment of the seed, âUnknits the sinews, parches up the heart, âConsumes unspent the treasury of thought, âThe fund and bullion, mint and coin of speech, âPalsies the silent wing of fantasy, âAnd sucks the marrow from the soul itself. âMan is the slave of everything he makes: âThis gold and silver, stamped and milled for ease âOf business, has become his sole concern: âEnough is not enough: we cannot breathe âWithout it: limpid water, healthy air âAre costly luxuries, the world has fallen âSo helplessly within the mean control âOf money! (How the symbol still usurps âAuthority in every province, masks âThe figure, drains the life of actual things! âNo vampire like ideas put to use!) âThis thing cannot be said; but he, the man âI call the greatest showed the Universe âThe acme of despair. A navvy, all âThe brute; bone, blood and brawn; brows like an ape's, âHawk's head, sad eyes deep-sunk, mouth leonine: âThe incarnation of the will to live, âAn instinct absolute. At twenty years âWith pick and shovel none could touch his skill, âNone face him hand to hand, none eat and drink âWith appetite so ravenous, so staunch, âSuch malt-proof brains; more glibly lewd in speech âThan creatures of debauch all gone to sex, âBut virginal in fancy and in deed. âOne evening in his twentieth year he sat âBeneath a hawthorn in a bottom-glade âThat fringed the northern suburb where he lived. âUpon its tranquil shadow every tree âIn golden light stood up, an emerald dome; âA vagrant wind that idled through the world, âFingering the lucent foliage wantonly, âAbout the quaint suburban valley trailed âThe scalloped oak-leaves, bronzed and fallen long, âThat caught its rustling mantle as it passed. âTrees with their wrinkled hides, their manyringed âCompacted boles, their heavy creaking boughs, âTheir myriad leaves, the green turf thick and sweet, âCream of the earth uprisen through fathomed depths âOf soil and sap: remembrances of these âOur natal house and only rafters once, âOur carpet, board and bed, a heritage âOccult in brain and blood, unguessed by him, âMy man of men, begat a passionate sense âOf everlastingness; as old, as young, âAs perdurable as the earth itself, âHe couched him in the wood and heard and felt. âAnon the travelling music of the street âThat distance can etherealize arose âAmong the workmen's houses overhead. âOld vogue or new, melodious tune or harsh, âHigh-hammered in the village, softly stole âAdown the neighbouring valley, deep, remote, âAntique, eternal as the world-old mood âOf him that listened dreaming. Every tree âUpon its shadow stood; athwart the boughs âThe wind, uncertain, sighed; the mellow tune âLike jewelled mist descended; moted shafts âOf dusky light escaped the journeying clouds âThat hid the ample sun and left his beams âA deeper hue of topaz, chrysosperm âTo milt the earth with harvest; thick as thoughts âA thunder of hoofs went byâfour grazing hacks âBy some unwonted shadow on the laund âPerturbed: a skirt, a glancing step, a shriek, âA ravished woman; and my man of men, âAt one with nature in the ancient way, âBegan his tragic course. A decade spent âIn prison turned him out, insane, corrupt, âThe sheath decayed, the weapon dim and hacked, âThe broken bits, the refuse of himself; âBut with a purpose smouldering in the dust, âThe ashes, embers, brands that had been once âA proper furnace and a glowing fire, âWith perilous temper in the worn-out blade, âWith wallflower on the ruins, a branch of stars âTo light the outcast in the sunless pit, âAnd music beating in the broken heart. âHe sought the ravished woman, and made her his; âFor now the world to him was sex alone, âAnd she, the other moiety of the world: âNone other; she, the woman of his deed, âHis fate, the only woman he had known. âThey lived beside the valley, sacro-sanct âTo him by reason of his sudden crime; âFor crime can hallow precincts, titles, tides, âAs certainly as Calvary remains âThe holiest spot on earth. Sometimes he wrought âWith pick and shovel like a thing wound-up; âSometimes in lethargy his days were sunk; âSometimes his passion for the woman welled âLike founts of living colour, founts of fire âThat steep the cloudy west in paradise. âThree years went by, a child with every year; âThen Fate abruptly gripped him by the throat, âAnd asked him of the deeds done in the flesh. âTo feed and clothe the woman his fiercest toil âRequired him still to starve himself. Four mouths âBeside his own! The hunger of his heart, âThe fury of his appetite, the blood âThat would ferment and flower; the toil, the pain, âThe hopeless time to come for him and his! âWhen the third child was twelve months old, and she, âThe lusty mother comelier every day, âAn orchard-tree with blossom and with fruit âSweet-scented and mature, this man of men, âUnwitting how the world shall cease to be, âAnd we and all our purpose, passion, power, âDissolve like snow in fire and leave no stain, âInstinctively achieved the greatest deed âRecorded hitherto; and answered Fate âWith utter arrogance. (The thing is known: âYou read the trial? No; it made no noise. âThat such a thing should happen in the world, âAnd pass from knowledge like a shallow jest!) âMidnight beat out upon suburban bells âA drowsy madrigal from tower to tower; âThe potent summer moonbeams thronged the room; âAnd when their youngest child, asleep at last, âReleased the woman virginal againâ âFor every birth restores virginity, âAnd a chaste year had filled the flower of hersâ âMy hero left his couch upon the floor, âApproached the bed where with her brood she lay, âAnd kneeling whispered in her ear. She blushedâ âHow deep a crimson mantling in the light âWith silvery bloom like clusters of the vine! âShe turned and kissed him, smiled and dove-like rose âAs willing as a bride. âOutside,â he said, âAnd pointed to the moon. In my heart of hearts I knew, As men must know whose will is set to truth, The death of Christ to be the tragic end Of God Himself that purged the world of Sinâ A great expedient indeed, and big With all transvaluation; but to think The desolating thought, to apprehend The meaning of the adamantine reign And power of Evolution in awful terms Of God and Judgement, overwhelmed my soul; And now that death at random tortures me, And delves and fathoms like a busy mole Tissue and marrow, now that maggots fret My brain and worms entangle fantasy, While casual darkness visits me by day, The shadow of the unknown, and dreams distress Me nightlyâ(all my household overhears The outcry of my waking); now, indeed Corroding consciousness of manhood gnaws And macerates the fibre of my mind With pangs of Hell and impotent remorse, So horrible and sick that sense of sin, In that archaic jargon dying hard, Were Heaven to such unutterable woe. It is my bones that speak, my skeleton, The inmost core of me, the soul of soul; The skeleton's the soul; it must be so. Once when I held the Wardenship in Hythe I handled souls; a cryptful there of bones Unsepulchred is worth a visit. Skull By skull I searched the infinite abyss Of empty sockets, till a valiant brow Engraved and cleft with sword and battle-axe Divulged its secret. Deep I dug my sight, Forehead to forehead, eye to eyeless gap As in a necromantic camera, Through Time and times to that tempestuous strand And moonlit battle in the roaring surf. Between two storms the beaten Saxons fell, All day pursued by ominous Vortimer And snared upon the threshold of the sea By hostile wind and tide, their old allies Become implacable antagonists. Thrust forth for flight warkeel on warkeel smote Amid the ravelled water; twisted prows Leapt up against the billows, spun aloft And burst in ragged splinters on the beach. Their helpless crews together madly hurled In writhing shoals, a wasted myriad, died. The remnant toed the tide mark, death behind And death in front. Extorting stride on stride The victors pressed them backward to the deep, Where dead and dying swashed against the limbs Of coupled combatants and dragged them down, Unstable shingle tripped and coiling surge Dislodged the surest foot. From the torn sky The placid bosom of the barren moon, Chill mirror of the morning, fitful light On cloven helmets flung and cleaving brands, On lips that snarled and eyes instinct with fate. Yet all unheard warcry and weapon rang, For high above the din of battle pealed The instant thunder of the brandished waves And shattering trumps and cymbals of the blast, While blood-shot foam in ruby-tinctured scrolls Unfurled and withered on the darkling shore. The combat vanished and a pageant thronged The chamber of the skull, presenting time Revoked through aeons to the earliest sun From nebulous stuff condensed which brimmed of yore That spacious womb the jewelled Zodiac claspsâ Ah, still the biassed Heaven!âI mean the loins Of ancient night with constellations girt. At once in molten rings as daughter-cells Are cleft and cleft again to don the shape Of perfect organs, from the spinning mass And staple of the Universe unscaled Like Saturn's girdles, satellites in germ, Earth and the neighbouring worlds, our known-unknown Adopted pagans (Vulcan, Mercury; The silver Venus, monogram of night And morning's crest; perfervid Mars that tempts A mundane hail; majestic Jupiter; The belted Saturn, prodigal in moons; Predicted Uranus and Neptune found Without a lens deep in the brain of man Upon the utmost verge of solar space)â Conglobing as they strained the million-miled Elastic tether gravitation gives, And shedding asteroids like fiery sweat, No way perplexed by vagrant comets, ghosts Perhaps of suns extinct that haunt in vain The wide, dynamic ether hoping still To reign resphered, these orbs of ours so cast Adrift in the infinite, eternally Assumed the measured pace and lonely path Celestial. Earth, delivered of its moon And chilled without and tempered to endure Barbaric sculpture of the glacier, shaped, Imbued, adorned by deluges, among the first Of planets felt the intolerable letch And prurience of Matter, the mystery, The viscid passion some call protoplasm And some call God; a mystery known to me For what it is, the whence and why unknown The Universe throughout; then half perceived Within the dinted skull, as Time revoked The pageant of Becoming from the storm And moonlit battle in the crimsoned surf To the primaeval nebula corrupt With life, that died and rotted into us, Our regal sun and pensionary orbs; And now that like a hive my body hums With pangs and muffled business of decay, A mystery deeply seen, retrieved and gripped In dogged apprehension, or as folk That perish hunger-clung their chapped lips bathe In native blood and in their proper flesh Their muzzles lock: for this is I, the thing I know and am: 'tis not my mind I speak: To speak one's mind? the itching vanity Of cancers, pustules, outcasts, parasites! It is my bones that speak, my skeleton: I speak the substance of the Universe. Yet, lost in sleep, my memory wakes and haunts Phantasmal regions ignorance of old In ecstasy inventedâbastioned cliffs, Indissoluble adamant on fire, By violet seas of burning sulphur washed And pierced by echoing caves of agony; Or islands of the evening plumed with fronds, Wine-coloured tides that in their slumbrous depths Mirror the purple twilight, golden shores Where rhythmic billows pulse like stricken lyres, And happy spirits in a waking dream Enjoy for ever disembodied bliss. Yet, yet I know that everywhere is Matter. Dreams of the dreams of Matter, Heaven and Hell In massed imaginings arose and flowered From world-old memories glimmering darkly still Through brain and bone of phosphorus knit, occult In carbon, calcium, metals, vapours, earths That build the body conscious and the soul Self-conscious. Could these elements elect, These changeful properties of Matter, one In all diversity, that chance or doom Delivered up to be mankind, forget Their burning passion in the nebula Though love itself came after? Never doubt That visions of Elysium and the abyss Of fire denote enduring thoughts antique As time of that supernal ecstasy, When Matter incandescent filled and rent The shuddering womb of universal spaceâ Material memories once the scourge of men, But now resolved and known for what they are. Yet they torment me? Yes, and terribly: Because the conscious Matter which I am, Beginning to surrender consciousness, Recoils from dissolution and divorce. To be dispersed in elemental sport Of heedless energyâthe uncontrolled Imagination of the Universe, That flashes out an instant nebula By chance encounter in the spacious dark Of ancient suns extinct and vagrant, turns To teeming wonder every water-drop, Afflicts the human race with hope, attunes The nightingale, and launches in the deep The monstrous rorqual: to be left once more A scattered wreck of groping elements Without remembrance, judgement, wisdom, choice, Perturbs the divers stuff that men are of; Wherefore when sleep in mimicry of death Dissolves self-consciousness, the hideous dreams That wake me shrieking. . . . Let them come again When sleep rehearses death, or death itself Takes up the cue: no dreams of mine are they, But Matter's dreams of old experience wrought In imperceptive atoms: while I wake I apprehend and master time and space, For this self-consciousness is masterdom.
